H0.text: Cool ocean currents circulating towards the equator increase the potential of a low‑pressure system, formed when air rises over the open ocean, to develop into a hurricane in the Northern Hemisphere.

H1.text: Increased volcanic activity in the upper latitudes increases the potential of a low pressure system developing into a hurricane in the Northern Hemisphere when air rises over the open ocean and a low pressure system is formed.

H2.text: Cold air moving south from the North Pole increases the potential of a low‑pressure system, formed when air rises over the open ocean, to develop into a hurricane in the Northern Hemisphere.

H3.text: Warm water temperatures in the tropics increase the potential of a low‑pressure system formed by rising air over the open ocean to develop into a hurricane in the Northern Hemisphere.

A4.text: Higher sea surface temperatures result in faster intensification rates and sometimes even rapid intensification.

A5.text: High ocean heat content, also known as Tropical Cyclone Heat Potential, allows storms to achieve a higher intensity.
